tenant_rights.title: Tenant Rights
tenant_rights.description: Laws protecting tenants under UK housing law

scenarios.applicable_law: Housing Act 1988 requires landlords to give 24 hours notice before entry except emergencies
scenarios.rights_summary: You have the right to quiet enjoyment of your property. Landlords must give at least 24 hours notice before entering except in genuine emergencies.
actions: Document unauthorized entries with dates and evidence
Send written complaint to landlord citing Housing Act 1988
Contact local council housing department
Seek advice from Shelter or Citizens Advice
Consider legal action for harassment if pattern continues

scenarios.applicable_law: Housing Act 2004 requires deposits to be protected in government-approved scheme within 30 days
scenarios.rights_summary: Your landlord must protect your deposit in an approved scheme and provide prescribed information within 30 days.
actions: Check if deposit is protected using scheme websites
Request prescribed information from landlord
Apply to county court for compensation (1-3x deposit amount)
Landlord cannot serve Section 21 notice if deposit not protected
Contact Shelter for guidance on court proceedings

scenarios.applicable_law: Equality Act 2010 protects against discrimination based on protected characteristics
scenarios.rights_summary: You have the right to work free from discrimination based on age, disability, gender, race, religion, sexuality, or other protected characteristics.
actions: Keep detailed records of discriminatory incidents
Follow internal grievance procedures first
Contact ACAS for free advice and mediation
File tribunal claim within 3 months less one day
Consider legal representation for complex cases

scenarios.applicable_law: Consumer Rights Act 2015 gives right to repair, replacement, or refund for faulty goods
scenarios.rights_summary: You have the right to goods that are of satisfactory quality, fit for purpose, and as described. You can get repair, replacement, or refund.
actions: Contact retailer immediately about fault
Allow one opportunity for repair or replacement
Request refund if repair/replacement fails
Use credit card chargeback if applicable
Report to Trading Standards if retailer refuses

scenarios.applicable_law: Contract law requires parties to perform obligations as agreed or face legal consequences
scenarios.rights_summary: You have the right to receive services as contracted and seek remedies including damages for breach.
actions: Review contract terms to identify specific breaches
Send formal letter before action citing breaches
Attempt resolution through complaint procedures
Consider mediation through trade association
File claim in appropriate court if necessary
